16-year-old boy is brought to the ER due to fever, vomiting, and irritability for 2 days. Vitals are thready pulse 120/min, BP is 80/60 mm Hg with cold clammy extremities. General physical examination shows petechiae on extremities, CNS examination shows nuchal rigidity and kernig sign. CBC show TLC of 25000 cells/ cu.mm and platelet count of 15,000/cu.mm Gram stain of CSF is shown and rest of the lab report is awaited. Which of the following is not correct about managment of this patient?

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fludrocortisone 

Explanation:

The patient is criticially sick and going into addisonian crisis due to Waterhouse-Friderichsen Syndrome

Gram stain reveals gram negative diploccoci which is neisseria meningitidis. The ongoing sepsis has caused DIC as suggested by low platelet count

Give Fluid boluses till pulse comes back to normal followed by 1L over next 1-2 hours which will restore the circulation of this patient.

IV hydrocortisone is DOC for addisonian crisis. IV ceftriaxone and vancomycin will be given to treat the sepsis

questions.text: 40-year-old woman diagnosed with cushing syndrome  presents with headaches and increased skin pigmentation over the past few months. She underwent a bilateral adrenalectomy six months ago. Which of the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Prevented by prophylactic radiation therapy before adrenalectomy
Occurs due to lack of negative feedback

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Low ACTH levels

Explanation:

ACTH levels are very high in Nelson syndrome since both adrenal glands have been resected leading to loss of negative feedback control. It can occur in patient with cushing disease refractory to surgery. The pre-existing corticotrope adenoma will expand in size to loss of check mechanism and will produce mass effects explaining the presenting complaints of this patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is first investigation to be performed in patient with ACTH dependant cushing syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MRI pituitary 

Explanation:

First investigation to be done in ACTH dependant cushing syndrome is MRI pituitary 

Elevated ACTH and elevated cortisol implies either endogenous cause or ectopic cause. MRI pituitary along with CRH test will help in identifying a pituitary adenoma

Option B: High dose dexamethasone suppression test helps to differentiate endogenous or ectopic cause. Failure to suppress cortisol production will imply ectopic source 

Option C: Low dose dexamethasone is a screening test for cushing syndrome 

Option D: Inferior petrosal sinus sampling petrosal/ peripheral ratio > 2 indicates endogenous cause 

First investigation to be done in ACTH independant cushing syndrome is CT abdomen

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of Cushing syndrome
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Menorrhagia 

Explanation

Cortisol suppresses GnRH and gonadotropin release causing amenorrhea and infertility and not menorrhagia 

Option A: Cortisol acts on ENac causing Hyprtension with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis 

Option B: Elevated steroids cause immune suppression. Eosinopenia is also seen

Option D: patients develop centripetal obesity with wasting of gluteal and proximal hip joint muscles

questions.text: 50-year-old man presents with severe cough for 3 months and hemoptysis episodes for past 3 days. Physical examination shows hypertension, purple abdominal wall striae, changes in hands as shown. Endobronchial lung biopsy is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Carcinoid tumor 

  • Clinical history points to diagnosis of cushing syndrome due to ectopic source.
  • Cushing features are hyperpigmentation of knuckes and IP joints with purpule striae on anterior abdominal wall, hypertension and centripetal obesity. 
  • Endobronchial biopsy report shows organoid nests of uniform cells and the nuclei with “salt and pepper” chromatin.
  • Oat cell cancer cells will be disorganised mass of cells with nuclei that will always looked crushed and squeezed. 

 

Carcinoid Tumor (Left Slide)

  • Uniform cells with abundant cytoplasm, round nuclei, and “salt and pepper” chromatin pattern.

  • Cells arranged in nesting or trabecular pattern with minimal mitosis and necrosis.

Oat Cell Cancer / Small Cell Lung Carcinoma (Right Slide)

  • Small round cells with scant cytoplasm, hyperchromatic nuclei, and nuclear molding.

  • Shows high mitotic activity, frequent necrosis, and crush artifacts due to fragile cells.

questions.text: 35 year old bollywood actor develops flushing episodes, asthma like symptoms and  frequent episodes of watery diarrhea . 24 hour urinary 5 HIAA levels are elevated. Which of the following drugs will be suitable for managment of GI complaints of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Somatostatin analogues

Explanation:

  • Somatostatin analogues are the first-line treatment for carcinoid syndrome. They inhibit secretion of serotonin and other vasoactive peptides, thereby controlling flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing 

Incorrect options- 

  • Telotristat ethyl blocks serotonin production by inhibiting tryptophan hydroxylase; used as adjunctive therapy for patients who don't fully respond to somatostatin analogues 
  • Loperamide acts on μ-opioid receptors in gut → ↓ motility, ↑ transit time. It works well in motility-driven diarrhea  like IBS-D and travelers’ diarrhea. 
  • Racecadotril is an enkephalinase inhibitor → ↑ endogenous enkephalins → ↓ cAMP-mediated secretion. It is useful in acute infectious diarrhea, but serotonin-mediated secretion in carcinoid is too strong, so inhibition is inadequate.

questions.text: 30 year old patient with pheochromocytoma is undergoing surgery for tumor resection. Which drug should be prepared by anaesthesiologist as a standy infusion and will not post operative hypotension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Nitroprusside

Explanation:

Blood pressure can be labile during pheochromocytoma surgery, particularly at the outset of intubation or when the tumor is manipulated.  Nitroprusside  infusion is useful for intraoperative hypertensive crises, and  hypotension usually responds to volume infusion.

The latter side  effect can, however, be avoided in normotensive pheochromocytoma patients by having only standby intraoperative nitroprusside, which has been shown to be safe and avoids postoperative hypotension
often caused by alpha blockers.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most sensitive and specific diagnostic test for detecting pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Plasma-free metanephrines

Explanation:

  • Plasma free metanephrine has been described a sensitivty of 4+ and specificity of 3+ 
  • 24 hour urinary fractionated metanephrine has sensitivity of 4+ and specificty of 2+ 
  • 4+ means > 95% and 3+ means 85-95% and 2+ is < 85% 

Hack to remember when use word Free vs fractionated in work up of pheochromocytoma:

  • Plasma is "free flowing" so we use free metanephrine values 
  • In contrast urine is filtered and has metabolically "fragmented or broken down products", so Fractionated metanephrine values

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for managment of pre-operative hypertension in pheochromocytoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Phenoxybenzamine + Propranolol 

Explanation 

Managing pheochromocytoma before surgery is critical to prevent life-threatening hypertensive crises during tumor manipulation. The standard approach includes:

1. Alpha-Blockade (FIRST and MANDATORY)

  • Drug: Phenoxybenzamine (non-selective, irreversible α-blocker)

  • Start: 10–14 days before surgery

2. Volume Expansion

  • Liberal salt and fluid intake (especially after adequate α-blockade)

  • Prevents postoperative hypotension

3. Beta-Blockade ( Never give before α-blockade – may precipitate hypertensive crisis by unopposed α-adrenergic action) 

  • Indication: If patient has persistent tachycardia or arrhythmias

  • Drug: Propranolol or atenolol

questions.text: Which of the following is imaging modality of choice for pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Gallium 68 dotatate PET/CT

 

Explanation:

Imaging modality with > 95% diagnostic sensitivity and specificity for pheochromocytoma is Gallium 68 dotatate PET/CT. Another test with similar diagnostic accuracy is 18Fluoro-DOPA PET/CT. The remaining options are stars of older years.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with persistent hypertension, weight gain, and muscle weakness. Lab results reveal elevated cortisol levels and suppressed ACTH. Which of the following is the next best investigation for work up of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CT abdomen 

Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical presentation, including elevated cortisol, suppressed ACTH, indicates an autonomous source of cortisol. Since we are suspecting adrenal adenoma / ACTH independant cushing syndrome , CT abdomen will be done. 
  • MRI pituitary and High dose dexamethasone suppression test is done in ACTH dependant cushing syndome. 
  • Low dose dexamethasone is done for confirmation of diagnosis but in this case the diagnosis is already made.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about case of mineralocorticoid excess?

choices.text: ACEi can cause false elevation of aldosterone

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) ACEi can cause false elevation of aldosterone

Explanation:

Excess aldosterone will cause increase in urinary excretion of potassium and hydrogen causing hypokalemic alkalosis 

Serum sodium can be normal inspite ot total body salt being more due to dilution caused by excess fluid retention 

Long standing hypokalemia can explain proximal myopathy 

ACEi must be stopped before testing since they will cause falsely low aldosterone and low ARR.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct abour primary addison disease?

choices.text: Skin color changes to pale alabaster

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)  Skin color changes to pale alabaster

Explanation:

A: Addison disease has salt wasting and volume depletion. This can lead to incresed serum creatinine 

B: Salt wasting explains orthostatic hypotension 

D: Low aldosterone explains hyponatermia with hyperkalemia. Remember aldosterone and potassium have inverse relation 

In primary addison disease , ACTH will rise due to feedback mechanism and will cause hyperpigmentation of skin. In contrast pale alabaster skin is seen in secondary addison disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of glucocorticoid deficiency
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B: Eosoinopenia 

Explanation:

Low glucocorticoids will cause hypoglycemia attacks.

Cortisol values and eosinophil count has inverse relation. Low cortisol is associated with high eosinophil count and vice versa.

Lack of cortisol causes loss of feedback inhibition of ADH release. This causes more ADH and resultant dilutional hyponatermia. 

Cortisol has partial aldosterone like activity.Less cortisol will cause Low BP

questions.text: Which part of the nephron is affected in Gordon syndrome?

choices.text: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Descending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Distal convoluted tubule

Explanation:

Gordon syndrome affects DCT.  It is caused by mutations that increase sodium-chloride reabsorption via the NCC (Na⁺/Cl⁻ cotransporter) in the DCT. this leads to low alosterone levels and hence it is also called Pseudohypoaldosteronism type IIA.  It leads to:

  1. Hypertension (due to volume expansion)

  2. Hyperkalemia (due to reduced potassium excretion)

  3. Metabolic acidosis

  4. Low renin and aldosterone levels

It is the opposite phenotype of Gitelman syndrome, which also involves the DCT but causes hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

 

Inheritance

Autosomal dominant (mostly)

Pathogenesis

Mutations in the WNK1, WNK4, CUL3, or KLHL3 genes result in abnormalities in serine/threonine kinases that dysregulate the thiazide-sensitive sodium-chloride cotransporter (NCC) in the distal nephron (Option A). This leads to increased sodium and chloride reabsorption, causing extracellular volume expansion and subsequent hypertension.

Clinical Presentation

Non-specific symptoms like muscle weakness, fatigue, hypertension (not always)

Laboratory Findings
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
  • Hypercalciuria
  • Low or low-normal plasma renin activity
  • Low serum aldosterone levels (relative to hyperkalemia)
  • Normal kidney function/normal glomerular filtration

Management
  • Correction of electrolyte abnormalities
  • Salt restriction
  • Thiazide diuretics

questions.text: All of the following are clinical manifestations of Liddle’s syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hyperaldosteronism

Explanation:

Aldosterone levels are suppressed in Liddle’s syndrome.

Liddle’s syndrome (pseudohyperaldosteronism):

Definition

An autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by hypertension with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hyporeninemia, and suppressed aldosterone secretion

Pathophysiology

Mutations in SCNN1A, SCNN1B, and SCNN1G genes → α, β, and γ subunits of ENaC (Epithelial Sodium Channel) altered → Increased Epithelial Sodium Channel activity→Elevated sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron → Sodium retention

Clinical features

- Early-onset hypertension (as early as 2 years of age) (Option C ruled out)

- Hypokalemia (Option A ruled out) and metabolic alkalosis

- Suppressed plasma renin (Option B ruled out) and aldosterone levels (Option D)

- Fatigue, muscle weakness, dizziness, and vision changes

Management

- Potassium-sparing diuretics: Amiloride or Triamterene

- Salt restriction

questions.text: 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent high blood pressure despite medication and muscle weakness. On examination BP is 170/100 mmHg. Work up shows results pH= 7.46, serum potassium: 3.2 mEq/L, serum sodium: 142 mEq/L and increased aldosterone levels. CT abdomen shows adrenal mass size of 2cm. Which of the following test is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B: Saline infusion test 

Explanation: 

  • Diagnosis based on hypertension with hypokalemic alkalosis is primary hyperaldosteronism. Since CT shows an adrenal mass, it would be conn syndrome. 

  • ARR is the correct initial test to screen for hyperaldosteronism and saline infusion test is a confirmatory test for diagnosis of Primary Hyperaldosteronism. 

  • ACTH stimulation test is used for adrenal insufficiency/ Addison disease. 

  • Dexamethasone suppression test evaluates cortisol excess (Cushing’s syndrome).

questions.text: 50-year-old hypertensive male presents with muscle weakness and frequent headaches. Work up shows hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with low plasma aldosterone and low renin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Liddle syndrome 

This patient has hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis — a triad suggesting mineralocorticoid excess. However, both plasma aldosterone and renin are low, ruling out primary (Conn syndrome) and secondary hyperaldosteronism . (option B and D ruled out). This points toward a condition that mimics aldosterone’s action despite its suppression. Liddle syndrome fits this profile: it is a genetic disorder where mutated ENaC channels in the distal nephron stay overactive, causing sodium retention and potassium loss, independent of aldosterone. Addison disease has hypotension and salt wasting and hence is ruled out.

questions.text: 30 year old patient presents with hypertension and hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. CT scan shows mass over the kidney of size 1.5 cm with elevated ARR. What is the next best step for management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Adrenal venous sampling 

Diagnosis is Conn syndrome as elevated aldosterone renin ratio is given in patient with adrenal mass with Hypertension 

Even if a CT scan shows an adrenal mass, AVS (adrenal venous sampling ) is needed to confirm lateralization of aldosterone production before surgery because:

1.  Coexistent non-functioning adrenal adenomas (incidentalomas) are common, especially in older adults.

2. The CT might show a mass, but it may not be the one producing aldosterone — and sometimes both glands are involved (bilateral hyperplasia).

AVS helps to differentiate between 

  • Unilateral disease → candidate for adrenalectomy
  • Bilateral disease → treated medically (e.g. with mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists like spironolactone or eplerenone)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with episodic headaches, palpitations, and excessive sweating. He is found to have labile hypertension and an adrenal mass on testing. Genetic testing confirms a ret proto-oncogene mutation, and ultrasound shows bilateral thyroid nodules. Which of the following is the major catecholamine produced by this tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Epinephrine 

Explanation:

 

Majority of pheochromocytoma are NE producing ( 80%) but in this question due to association with MEN 2/ Sipple syndrome the answer is epinephrine producing. The presence of ret gene and thyoid masses indictate a medullary carcinoma of thyroid that could be present. 

Pheochromocytomas arise from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla (or extra-adrenal paraganglia).

These tumors lack cortisol exposure needed to activate the enzyme phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PNMT), which converts norepinephrine to epinephrine.

Hence, overall norepinephrine is the predominant secretion in ~80% of pheochromocytomas.
